name: Advice on employment rights

children.text: COVID-19, Workers' Rights, and the Return to Work
It is still the case that those who can work from home should continue to do so. General bars, restaurants etc shouldn't be re opening unless they are doing a takeaway service.

Advice from the government about who should and shouldn't be at work has been a bit confusing but as of the week commencing 10 May supermarket workers, manufacturing workers, laboratory and research workers, construction workers, and those in delivery and distribution should be working. A lot of people in these sectors have already been working through the crisis anyway, but this will result in more people going back.

If your employer is using the furlough scheme and has furloughed you they should not be asking you to do any work. You're either on furlough or you aren't. They might require you to do training – guidance on this seems a bit ambiguous.
Employers have a lot of legal responsibilities under various health and safety laws including

* The general responsibility to provide a safe working environment
* The responsibility to provide adequate personal protective equipment (PPE)
* The responsibility to carry out risk assessments
* The obligation to consult their workers on health and safety issues

If you have a recognised union in your workplace make sure you have elected some Health & Safety Reps. Employers should share the results of risk assessments with these reps and consult with them. These reps can also carry out their own risk assessments and conduct inspections of workplaces to identify hazards and threats to health and safety.
Even if you don't have a union there is still provision in law to be consulted by employers about health and safety.
Case law seems to suggest that health and safety risk assessments also apply to travelling to and from work so bear this in mind if you have to use public transport.

Section 44 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 gives employees the right to refuse to work if they believe doing so would pose a 'serious and imminent danger' to health. This is an individual right and you cannot lawfully be penalised for exercising it – for example if your employer sacked you for exercising this right it would automatically be an unlawful dismissal. It is a right based on your sincerely held opinion, regardless of what your employer thinks. So even if they say “Well we've implemented X,Y, and Z,” that doesn't matter, if you believe that a 'serious and imminent danger' exists. Please see this blog from the Trades Union Congress for more information
If you are having problems with safty at work you can report to the Health and Safety Executive by telephone on

. Lines are open Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 10pm.

Sheffield Heeley MP Louise Haigh is also willing to discuss concerns and report anonymously on your behalf, see
All employees also have a general responsibility not to put themselves or anyone else in danger.

Make sure your managers are aware of these rights and responsibilities because unless your company head office has told them, they probably won't be. Managers should be aware that in some cases they can end up liable for breaches of health and safety law (as can employees).
Groups of workers across the country and around the world have called for various things including:

* Maintaining physical distancing in workplaces, or using barriers (e.g. plexiglass guards) where this isn't possible
* COVID-19 tests for workers or, where this isn't available, temperature tests to check if anyone is running a fever
* Full pay for those off sick/isolating – this is a health and safety issue as there will no doubt be people that go to work ill if they would otherwise not be paid their full wage
* Extra steps to protect workers that fall into one or more of the vulnerable categories (including pregnant workers)

Remember that legal requirements should be treated as a minimum. When it comes to sick pay, health and safety measures (and indeed anything else) we should be demanding more than the bare minimum to keep ourselves, our colleagues, and the public safe. Check your contract of employment as it may contain clauses that go beyond the legal minimum.

Most importantly - get together with your colleagues and talk about whether you are happy with the measures your employer is taking. You will always be stronger acting together than alone. Join a union if you are not already in one and encourage your colleagues to do so. These health and safety responsibilities are required whether you have a union or not but you will always be stronger with collective organisation.

name: Support for Detainees (Immigration Detention)

children.text: Anyone who does not have the right to remain is liable to be held in immigration detention. This can happen at any time, but there are several points in the asylum and immigration process when people are more likely to be detained :-
when claiming asylum, if the Home Office categorise the case as a Dublin safe third country case, or as a non-suspensive appeals case. This will happen after the screening interview.
if the person has claimed asylum, been refused and is "appeal rights exhausted".
if the person does not have any immigration status or applications pending and is picked up by an immigration enforcement team.
It is common for someone at risk of detention to be picked up when they go for their regular reporting/signing event at the Home Office.

People detained under immigration powers may be detained in an immigration removal centre (IRC) or short-term holding facility, or if they are a foreign national ex-offender who has completed their custodial sentence they may continue to be detained in prison. The Home Office uses the term Immigration Removal Centre but many people are held in detention for long periods of time with no prospect of removal/deportation.

Those detained are entitled to see a doctor within 24 hours, and there will be duty solicitors available. It is possible to visit detainees but this has to be pre booked. The list of Immigration Removal Centres and details of how to arrange a visit are

Unless there are very exceptional circumstances, nobody should be detained who has been tortured, has serious health problems which cannot be adequately managed in detention, or whose health is likely to be damaged by continued detention.

name: Care Act Support

children.text: If an asylum seeker (age 18+) has significant care and support needs that are related to a physical or mental health issue, illness or disability, they might be able to get housing, financial and other support from the Local Authority social services.​
help to challenge Care Act refusals
The local authority will undertake a two stage assessment:

: the threshold to carry out an assessment is very low. The council has a duty to assess as long as there is the appearance of need. They will assess:
- Does the person ordinarily live in the area. In cases where people are of no fixed abode, the intention to stay in the locality is sufficient.
- Are they in immediate need of being housed?

: The threshold for being eligible for support is very high. The person's needs must relate to physical or mental impairment or illness, and must not be a result of them being destitute. The person must be unable to achieve at least two of the following outcomes and this must have an impact on their wellbeing. These outcomes are:
- Managing nutrition
- Managing toilet needs
- Maintaining personal hygiene
- Making use of community facilities and services.

Note that some refused asylum seekers can only get care and support from social services if this is necessary to prevent a breach of their human rights, so social services will need to carry out a human rights assessment to establish whether support can be provided. This has three Stages
1. Can they freely return to their country of origin?

Is there an obstacle to returning, such as missing travel documents, illness that means they can’t fly, outstanding appeal to the HO? If there is a temporary barrier, support could be given temporarily until the barrier is removed and reviewed regularly. If there is an insurmountable barrier to return, refusing support will probably be a breach of HR
2. What would be the impact of return to their Country of origin on their human rights and would they be breached?
In the case of refused asylum seekers, the opinion of the Home Office is usually available (refusal letter detailing why they believe that the person is not in need of protection).

However, asylum seekers would need to be given the opportunity to seek legal advice to prove that return would breach their Human Rights. It is not sufficient to say that no comparable medical facilities exist in the Country of Origin .
3. Impact on family and private life
What social and family ties the person has in the UK and whether these could be maintained. Right to family life is a relative right and can be breached if proportionate to legitimate public end.

children.text: From 25 March, no face-to-face appeal hearings will be listed at the First-tier Tribunal (the court where most asylum and immigrationare be heard).

Until at least 30 April, judges will conduct Case Management Review Hearings by telephone to decide if the case can be decided on the papers (without a hearing). A CMR hearing is a pre-hearing (which already happened in some asylum cases) at which the judge decides whether the appellant and the Home Office are ready to proceed with the full hearing a few weeks later.
If it decided that a full hearing needs to go ahead, this will be done by video.

Beware of fraud and scams during the COVID-19 pandemic

Criminals all over the world are using the COVID-19 crisis to scam the public, targeting vulnerable groups in particular. Action Fraud, the UK’s national fraud reporting service, reported a 400% increase in coronavirus-related fraud in March 2020.
The Crown Prosecution Service has shared the following advice:
Stop: Taking a moment to stop and think before parting with your money or information could keep you safe.
Challenge: Could it be fake? It’s ok to reject, refuse or ignore any requests. Only criminals will try to rush or panic you.
Protect: If you have a bank account contact your bank immediately if you think you’ve fallen for a scam and report it to Action Fraud.

We have gone through the various reports of scamming and made a list for you to watch out for. Please note that the list is by no means exhaustive, and criminals can find other ways of targeting individuals so always be vigilant.

• Virus Testing: Virus testing kits are only offered by the NHS in the UK.
• Vaccines/Cures: There is currently no vaccine or cure for COVID-19.
• Counterfeit Products: There has been a surge in overpriced or fake goods to protect yourself from the coronavirus. These include antibacterial gels, masks etc.
• Shopping/Medication Delivery: Criminals targeting vulnerable people on their doorstep and offering to do their shopping or deliver medicine.
• Cleaning Services: Offering cleansing services to prevent spread of the virus.
• Phishing emails/text messages: Beware of messages tricking you into opening malicious
attachments which could lead do fraudsters gaining access to personal information.
The following e-mails have been identified by Action Fraud:

1. Fraudsters pretending to be from a research group that mimic the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and World Health Organisation (WHO). They claim to provide the victim with a list of active infections in their area.
2. Fraudsters providing articles about the virus outbreak with a link to a fake company website where victims are encouraged to click to subscribe to a daily newsletter for further updates.
3. Fraudsters sending investment scheme and trading advice encouraging people to take
advantage of the coronavirus downturn.
4. Fraudsters pretending to be from HMRC offering a tax refund and directing victims to a fake website to collect their personal and financial details.
If you or someone you know has been a targeted by a scam, you should report it to Action Fraud
For advice and information on how to check if something might be a scam, visit the CAB website

children.text: Modern slavery is an umbrella term, encompassing human trafficking, slavery, servitude and forced labour. name: Looking After Yourself Physically and Mentally During Covid-19

children.text: · While we are in lockdown due to Covid 19 it is important for us to look after ourselves both physically and mentally.

· Staying at home waiting with nothing to do is very challenging for everyone and can leave us with a range of feelings. This can often include feeling lonely, depressed, helpless and with a sense of having lost something. We are all learning new ways of how to pass the time and stay healthy.
There is helpful material with practical tips to help you cope with anxious times translated into a variety of languages available in our printable resources.
Psychology Tools have made a useful self help guide with worksheets around living with anxiety available in a wide variety of languages
· We all have so many questions about Covid 19 many of which cannot be answered at the moment. It is easy to feel powerless and that everything is out of control.

When we feel this, it can be very helpful to focus on what we DO have control over and take each day at a time. We may be surprised and overwhelmed by our feelings, but we can be in charge of what we do each day.
Here are 4 different ways that we can begin to take control of our daily life and look after ourselves.
· It is important to try and create some structure to your day. We all need some routine in our lives
· You can decide what time you get up.
· You can plan what you are going to eat and cook.
· You can decide when you are go outside
· You can decide where you will walk to.
· We are all allowed to go out to exercise once a day if we are not shielding. We just need to make sure we keep 2 metres apart from people that we are not living with.
· It is important to exercise to keep your body healthy;
· If you sit at home and do not go out, your body gives your brain the message that you are helpless and powerless, and this is not true.
· The most important thing is to MOVE.
· You can do this at home, but it is important to vary your surroundings.
· Going out in the sunlight provides us with important Vitamin D and fresh air.
· You can walk to a park. You do not need to just walk the streets.
· We can provide you with a list of the parks in the city and the ones near you.
· We have also designed some walks for you that you can follow. See printable resources.
Using your hands to do something is an excellent way to keep your mind occupied. It helps to give your mind a task which you have to focus on.
Here are some examples. Are there any you like or that you have done before?
· Cutting things out – Making scrap books of things that make us happy/Creative Writing
· Contact the Migrant Covid-19 Group if you would like some activities sent to you - see provider details for contact numbers.
· Do you have someone who you can talk to regularly?
· If not, would you like to speak to someone regularly through the Migrant Covid-19 Support Group? Please get in touch if you do - see provider details for contact numbers.

These are the current rules around when face coverings are required in England
You must wear a face covering at all times on public transport or when attending a hospital as a visitor or outpatient. Hospitals will be able to provide a face covering in emergencies.

If you can, you should also wear a face covering in other enclosed public spaces where social distancing isn’t possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet. This is most relevant for short periods indoors in crowded areas. From 24th July 2020 face coverings will be mandatory in supermarkets and all other shops.
You should be prepared to remove your face covering if asked to do so by police officers and staff for the purposes of identification.

Face coverings do not replace social distancing. If you have symptoms of COVID-19 (cough, and/or high temperature, and/or loss of, or change in, your normal sense of smell or taste), you and your household must isolate at home: wearing a face covering does not change this.

Face coverings should not be used by children under the age of 3 or those who may find it difficult to manage them correctly. For example, primary age children unassisted, or those with respiratory conditions. Children under 11 are exempt from wearing face coverings on public transport and in shops.

If someone cannot wear a face covering for medical reasons they can download a travel assistance card which explains this from Travel South Yorkshire. This is available in printable resources. NHS Sheffield has also produced cards that explain why a person is not wearing a mask which can be printed or used on a mobile phone - see printable resources.
Face Coverings and Masks - how to wear them safely
It is important to use face coverings properly and wash your hands before putting them on and taking them off.
A cloth face covering should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably. It can be as simple as a scarf or bandana that ties behind the head.

Wash your hands or use hand sanitiser before putting it on and after taking it off. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all times and store used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them.

Do not touch the front of the face covering, or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose. Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched.

You should wash a face covering regularly. It can go in with other laundry, using your normal detergent, wash at 60 degrees centigrade. You can also handwash using detergent in hot water - wash by hand for at least five minutes.
When wearing a face covering, take care to tuck away any loose ends.
